{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:BQ''' is the entry for [[Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba, special municipalities of the [[Netherlands]], ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba#Administration|3 special municipalities]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|BQ}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba. The second part is two letters. Each special municipality is also assigned their own ISO 3166-2 code under the [[ISO 3166-2:NL|entry for the Netherlands]].{{cite web|title=ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-8 (2010-12-15):Code elements for Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Curaçao and Sint Maarten (Dutch part), update of other territories and minor correction|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-1_newsletter_vi-8_split_of_the_dutch_antilles_final-en.pdf|date=15 December 2010|accessdate=1 January 2011|publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]}} ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]), ([[Dutch language|nl]]) ! Subdivision name ([[Papiamentu language|pap]]) ! Netherlands ISO 3166-2 code |- | {{mono|BQ-BO}} | [[Bonaire]] | Boneiru | [[ISO 3166-2:NL|{{mono|NL-BQ1}}]] |- | {{mono|BQ-SA}} | [[Saba]] | Saba | [[ISO 3166-2:NL|{{mono|NL-BQ2}}]] |- | {{mono|BQ-SE}} | [[Sint Eustatius]] | Sint Eustatius | [[ISO 3166-2:NL|{{mono|NL-BQ3}}]] |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry had been announced in newsletters by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Addition of code to align ISO 3166-1 and ISO 3166-2, addition of two divisions and update of the number of divisions. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:BQ ISO Online Browsing Platform: BQ] * [http://www.statoids.com/ubq.html Caribbean Netherlands], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:BQ]] [[Category:Dutch Caribbean]]

[[File:LocationGuatemala.svg|thumb|350px|[[Guatemala]]'s location in [[Central America]].]] {{Main|Guatemala}} The following is an alphabetical list of '''topics related to the [[Republic of Guatemala]]'''. {{Compact ToC|center=yes|align=center|seealso=yes|notesfirst=|extlinks=yes|refs=yes|sep=·}}
==0–9== [[File:Un-guatemala.png|thumb|500px|A map of [[Guatemala]].]] * [[.gt]] – [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]] for Guatemala
==A== * [[ADIVIMA]] * '''Adjacent countries:''' :{{BLZ}} :{{SLV}} :{{HND}} :{{MEX}} * [[Air Force of Guatemala]] * [[List of airports in Guatemala|Airports in Guatemala]] * [[Ak'tenamit]] * [[Americas]]<ref name=Americas>The division of the [[Americas]] into the [[continent]]s of [[North America]] and [[South America]] is somewhat arbitrary. Most commonly, [[Panama]] is considered to be a part of North America and [[Colombia]] is considered a part of [[South America]]. [[Geology|Geologically]], the boundary between the two continents is defined by the boundary between the [[Caribbean Plate]] and the [[South American Plate]]. This places the boundary roughly along the Panama-Colombia border. Other definitions place the boundary at the lowest natural crossing of the [[Isthmus of Panama]] near the [[Panama Canal]], or along the canal itself. Another definition places the boundary at the lowest crossing of [[Central America]] near [[Lake Nicaragua]]. This definition splits Central America between the continents of North and South America.</ref> ** [[North America]]<ref name=North_America>Greater [[North America]] may be [[Geography|geographically]] subdivided into [[Northern America]], [[Central America]], and the [[Caribbean]].</ref> *** [[Central America]]<ref name=Central_America>Central America is defined as the southeasternmost extent of North America, most commonly including the seven nations of [[Belize]], [[Guatemala]], [[El Salvador]], [[Honduras]], [[Nicaragua]], [[Costa Rica]], and [[Panama]].</ref> **** [[Islands of Guatemala]] ***** [[North Atlantic Ocean]] ****** ''[[Mar Caribe]]'' ([[Caribbean Sea]]) ***** [[North Pacific Ocean]] * [[Army of Guatemala]] * '''[[commons:Atlas of Guatemala|Atlas of Guatemala]]''' * [[La Aurora International Airport]]

{{news release|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = Institution of Environmental Sciences | image = Institution of Environmental Sciences logo.jpg | image_size = 125px | type = [[Professional body]] | founded_date = 1971 | founder = [[Julian Snow, Baron Burntwood]] | location_city = [[London Wall]]
[[London]], {{postcode|EC|2}}
United Kingdom | area_served = World wide | focus = [[Environmental Science]] | method = Education, advice, support, CPD | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[John Lawton (biologist)|John Lawton]] | key_people = Adam Donnan (CEO) | homepage =[http://www.the-ies.org www.the-ies.org] }} '''The Institution of Environmental Sciences''' (IES) is a UK professional body leading debate, dissemination and promotion of environmental science and sustainability. The IES has ties with [[higher education]] and promotes and supports environmental sciences and [[sustainable development]] in universities and colleges nationally and internationally. The IES is a charitable organisation, which raising public awareness of [[environmental science]] by supporting professional scientists and academics working in the area. IES is a constituent body of both the [[Society for the Environment]] (SocEnv), and the [[Science Council]] which enables IES members to progress to [[Chartered Environmentalist]]{{cite web|url=http://www.socenv.org.uk/members/list-of-member-bodies/|title=Licensed Partners|work=socenv.org.uk|accessdate=2 Jan 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820024214/http://www.socenv.org.uk/members/list-of-member-bodies/|archivedate=2007-08-20|df=}} and [[Chartered Scientist]]{{cite web|url=http://sciencecouncil.org/about-us/our-members-and-licensed-bodies/|title=Licensed Partners|work=sciencecouncil.org/|accessdate=2 Jan 2016}} status ==History== The Institution of Environmental Sciences was founded as a result of an initiative by Dr John Rose during a series of meetings held during 1971-1972 at the Royal Society in London and chaired by Lord Burntwood. ==Affiliations== The IES is a member of the [[Society for the Environment]], the [http://www.sciencecouncil.org Science Council] and the [http://www.efaep.org European Network of Environmental Professionals]. The IES provides administration for two sister organisations. The [http://www.ches.org.uk/ Committee of Heads of Environmental Science] who accredit programmes of study in universities and to support and promote the discipline in higher education and the [[Institute of Air Quality Management]]. ==Publications== The IES produces four editions of its journal '''environmental SCIENTIST''' each year. Articles are written by experts and professionals working in the environmental field. Each issue examines a topic of importance to environmental science; an expert in the area acts as guest editor, introducing the articles and providing an overview of the subject at hand. Previous editions of the journal can be viewed on the [http://www.the-ies.org/environmental_scientist IES website]. The IES produces reports that are available to download from [http://www.the-ies.org/reports the website]. In addition to the journal and reports, the IES produces a monthly newsletter, '''ES News''', focusing on a lighter dissemination of expert knowledge and the sharing of institution news. ==See also== * [[Chartered Environmentalist]] * [http://www.charteredscientist.org Chartered Scientist] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.the-ies.org IES website] * [http://www.iaqm.co.uk IAQM website] [[Category:Environmental organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Environmental organizations established in 1971]] [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Organisations based in the City of London]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United Kingdom|Environmental Sciences]]

revision.text:
'''Lester George''' is a internationally renowned [[golf course]] [[architect]] who was born in [[Wiesbaden]], [[Germany]] in 1955 while his father was stationed there by the United States Air Force.
After attending The [[University of Richmond]], where he founded the school’s [[orienteering]] team, George settled in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. Following college graduation in 1977, he spent four years in the army as an artillery officer, subsequently received his Master’s Degree from the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College]] and remained in the Army Reserves until retiring a [[Lieutenant Colonel]] in 2003. This military career coincided with the development of his career as a golf course architect.<ref>http://georgegolfdesign.com/-lester-george</ref>
Prior to opening his own firm in 1991, George studied with other golf course architects at Golf Services International learning all aspects of golf course design and construction. He attended the Harvard Design School, Golf Course Architecture in 1992, which launched his solo career. George's company, George Golf Design, Inc., is located in Midlothian, Virginia, just outside Richmond. George is a member of the [[American Society of Golf Course Architects]].<ref>http://www.asgca.org/members/82?mid=71</ref>
George has developed a niche in renovating and restoring classic golf courses designed by some of the most revered golden age architects such as MacDonald, Raynor, Tillinghast, Ross, Flynn, Tull and Wilson - and he has worked with many of the most historic and well-regarded golf facilities on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] (see project listings below).
Lester George donated much time and effort to the First Tee Program designing and overseeing construction of The First Tee of Chesterfield, the premiere 18-hole First Tee course in the United States.
Using abandoned [[landfill]]s as a canvas, George successfully transforming two [[brownfield land|brownfields]] into golf courses—converting overgrown hazardous areas into plush, green recreational turf. One of these courses, Lambert's Point Golf Course in Norfolk, Virginia, won an Affinity Award for Environmental Stewardship from the Golf Course Builders Association of America.
George's renovation of the Raptor course at Langley Air Force Base posed a challenge when thousands of unexploded bombs were discovered on the site once excavation began.
George’s projects have won numerous awards:<ref>http://georgegolfdesign.com/-awards-and-recognition</ref>
'''Ballyhack Golf Club''', Roanoke, VA * #3, Best New Private Course of 2009, Golf Magazine * Top Ten Best New Courses, Golf Magazine * Top Ten Best New Courses, Links Magazine * Top 20 Premiere Clubs in American Golf, Links Magazine
'''The Colonial Golf Course''', Williamsburg, VA * The Top Ten You Can Play, Golf Magazine One of The Best New Courses in America, The Golfer Magazine * Top 100 Reasons to Play Golf, The Washington Golf Monthly
'''Kinloch Golf Club''', Manakin‐Sabot, VA * Hosted US Senior Amateur in 2011 * Best New Private Course of 2001, Golf Digest #1 Course in Virginia, Golf Digest #4, Readers Choice Awards, Golf World * # 9 ‐ # 23, 100 Greatest Modern Golf Courses, GolfWeek #13, Top 100 Modern Courses, GolfWeek * #33 of 100 Greatest Courses, Golf Digest * #48, Top 100 in America, Golf Digest * Top 18 One‐Time Collaborations in Golf Course Architecture, Links Magazine * Top 20 Premiere Clubs in American Golf, Links Magazine
'''The James River Course at The Country Club of Virginia''', Richmond, VA * #5, Best New Remodel of 2005, Golf Digest
'''Lamberts Point''', Norfolk, VA * Environmental Stewardship Affinity Award, Golf Course Builders Association of America
'''Lakeview Golf Course''', Harrisonburg, VA * Best Places to Play, Golf Digest * Valley’s Best Golf Course, Daily News Record
'''The Newport Bay Course at Ocean City Golf & Yacht Club''', Berlin, MD * Top 100 Reasons to Play Golf, The Washington Golf Monthly
'''The Old White Course at The Greenbrier''', White Sulphur Springs, WV * Best New Public Remodel of 2007, Golf Digest 2006 Legacy Award #12 Resort Course, Conde Nast Traveler * Best Restoration, Golf Course Builders Association * One of 100 Greatest Classic Golf Courses, GolfWeek * Hosting the PGA Tour’s Greenbrier Classic
'''Providence Golf Course''' * Rated 4 ½ Stars by Golf Digest Magazine * Rated Second Best Golf Course in Richmond Area, Richmond Times Dispatch
'''Rock Manor Golf Course''', Wilmington, DE * Best Public Golf Course, Delaware Today
'''Willow Oaks Country Club''', Richmond, VA * #8, Best New Remodel of 2008, Golf Digest Magazine * Hosted State Open Tournament
'''Lester George''' * One of the Course Architects of Year, The Board Room Magazine * Achievement in Golf Course Design, ING Industry Honors * One of the Leading Young Architects in the Country, Golf World * Design Excellence Award, American Society of Golf Course Architects
Lester George's golf course designs include the following:<ref>http://georgegolfdesign.com/-project-history</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Mammoth Cave tour.jpg|thumb|right|290px|[[Mammoth Cave]], the longest known cave system in the United States and the world]] The following is a list of the longest [[caves]] in the [[United States]] per length of documented passageways. Many passageways are still being discovered; this list is based on the latest verifiable data.{{cite web| last = Gulden | first = Bob | title = USA Longest Caves | date = January 6, 2018 | url = http://www.caverbob.com/usalong.htm | accessdate = 1 August 2018}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !System !Length !Location !Associated parks,
protected areas |- valign="top" |[[Mammoth Cave]] |{{convert|651.8|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Brownsville, Kentucky]] | [[Mammoth Cave National Park]], also a [[World Heritage Site]] and International [[Biosphere Reserve]]. Longest cave in the world.{{cite web| last = Gulden | first = Bob | title = Worlds Longest Caves | date = January 7, 2018 | url = http://www.caverbob.com/wlong.htm | accessdate = 1 August 2018}} |- valign="top" |[[Jewel Cave]] |{{convert|310.7|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Custer, South Dakota]] |[[Jewel Cave National Monument]] |- valign="top" |[[Wind Cave]] |{{convert|236.7|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Hot Springs, South Dakota]] |[[Wind Cave National Park]] |- valign="top" |[[Lechuguilla Cave]] |{{convert|222.6|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Carlsbad, New Mexico]] |[[Carlsbad Caverns National Park]] |- valign="top" |[[Fisher Ridge Cave System]] |{{convert|201.6|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Brownsville, Kentucky]] |none |- valign="top" |[[Friars Hole Cave System]] |{{convert|75.5|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Renicks Valley, West Virginia]] |none |- valign="top" |[[Indiana Caverns|Binkley's Cave System]] |{{convert|71.1|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Corydon, Indiana]] |none |- valign="top" |[[Hellhole]] |{{convert|67.9|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |[[Germany Valley]], [[West Virginia]] |none |- valign="top" |[[Kazumura Cave]] |{{convert|65.5|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |[[Pahoa, Hawaii]] |none |- valign="top" |[[Blue Spring Cave]] |{{convert|64.4|km|sp=us|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} |near [[Sparta, Tennessee]] |none |} ==See also== *[[List of caves]] *[[List of longest caves]] *[[List of deepest caves]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Caves}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of longest caves in the United States}} [[Category:Caves]] [[Category:Lists of caves]] [[Category:Geography-related lists of superlatives]]

[[File:Bln Tiergarten Luiseninsel.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Luiseninsel at Großer Tiergarten.]]
The following is a list of notable parks, gardens, and outdoor spaces in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]].
==Zoos== * [[Berlin Zoological Garden]] * [[Tierpark Berlin]]
==Parks== * [[Barnim Nature Park]] * [[Großer Tiergarten]] * [[Grunewald (forest)]] * [[Henriette Herz Park]] * [[Körnerpark]] * [[Mauerpark]] * [[Pfaueninsel]] * [[Treptower Park]] * [[Tempelhofer Feld]] - A park opened in 2010 at the former site of [[Berlin Tempelhof Airport]] * [[Viktoriapark]] * [[Volkspark Friedrichshain]] * [[Volkspark Mariendorf]]
==Gardens==
* [[Botanical Garden in Berlin]] * [[Britzer Garten]] * [[Erholungspark Marzahn]]<ref>http://www.gruen-berlin.de/parks-gaerten/gaerten-der-welt/ueberblick/</ref>
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Parks in Berlin [http://www.berlinfo.com/Freetime/Recreation/parks/index.htm] {{Parks in Berlin |state=autocollapse}} {{Berlin}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = S. H. Hasbullah | honorific_suffix = | native_name = எஸ். எச். ஹஸ்புல்லாஹ் | native_name_lang = ta | image = Professor Shahul Hasbullah.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1950|9|3|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Erukkulampiddy]], [[Dominion of Ceylon|Ceylon]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|08|25|1950|9|3|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Jaffna]], [[Sri Lanka]] | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = {{Ubl|[[University of Sri Lanka]]|[[University of British Columbia]]}} | occupation = Academic | religion = | denomination = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Shahul Hameed Hasbullah''' ({{lang-ta|சாஹுல் ஹமீத் ஹஸ்புல்லாஹ்|translit=Cāhul Hamīt Haspullāh}}; 3 September 1950 – 25 August 2018) was a [[Sri Lanka]]n social activist, geographer and academic.
==Early life and family== Hasbullah was born on 3 September 1950 in [[Erukkulampiddy]] in northern [[Dominion of Ceylon|Ceylon]].<ref name="CT250818">{{cite news |title=Professor Shahul H. Hasbullah (3 September 1950 – 25 August 2018) |url=https://www.colombotelegraph.com/index.php/professor-shahul-h-hasbullah-3-september-1950-25-august-2018/ |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=Colombo Telegraph |date=25 August 2018}}</ref><ref name="Th250818">{{cite news |title=பேராசிரியர் S.H. ஹஸ்புல்லாஹ் காலமானார் |url=http://www.thinakaran.lk/2018/08/25/%E0%AE%89%E0%AE%B3%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%A8%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%9F%E0%AF%81/26448/%E0%AE%AA%E0%AF%87%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%9A%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%AF%E0%AE%B0%E0%AF%8D-sh-%E0%AE%B9%E0%AE%B8%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%AA%E0%AF%81%E0%AE%B2%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%B2%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%B9%E0%AF%8D-%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%B2%E0%AE%AE%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%A9%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%B0%E0%AF%8D |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=[[Thinakaran]] |date=25 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka |language=Tamil}}</ref> He was educated at Erukkulampiddy Central College.<ref name="ST260818">{{cite news |title=Prof. Hasbullah passes away |url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/180826/news/prof-hasbullah-passes-away-308178.html |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=[[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)|The Sunday Times]] |date=26 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref> He obtained a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A]] [[Academic degree|degree]] from the [[Peradeniya]] campus of the [[University of Sri Lanka]] in 1975.<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="Th250818"/> He also received [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degrees from the [[University of British Columbia]].<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="Th250818"/><ref name="SHSU">{{cite web |title=SHSU Update for Week of Oct. 20 |url=http://www.shsu.edu/~pin_www/T@S/2002/Oct202002.html |publisher=[[Sam Houston State University]] |accessdate=25 August 2018 |location=Huntsville, U.S.A.}}</ref>
Hasbullah had a son and two daughters.<ref name="Th250818"/>
==Career== Hasbullah was professor of geography at the [[University of Peradeniya]].<ref name="CT250818"/> He was a [[visiting scholar]] at the [[University of Zurich]], [[University of Edinburgh]], [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]] and University of British Columbia (2004).<ref name="CT250818"/> He was a visiting [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] scholar at [[Georgetown University]]'s [[Institute for the Study of International Migration]].<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="SHSU"/>
Hasbullah was a resource person during the 2003 Sri Lankan peace talks and was member of the Sub-committee on Immediate and Humanitarian Needs of the War-torn Areas of Sri Lanka.<ref name="CT250818"/> He was a [[University Grants Commission (Sri Lanka)|UGC]] appointed member of the [[University council|council]] of the [[University of Jaffna]].<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="UoJ">{{cite web |title=The Council |url=http://www.jfn.ac.lk/index.php/the-council/ |publisher=[[University of Jaffna]] |accessdate=25 August 2018 |location=Jaffna, Sri Lanka}}</ref> He was a member of the board of directors of the International Centre for Ethnic Studies (ICES).<ref name="ICES">{{cite web |title=Board of Directors |url=http://ices.lk/board-of-directors/ |publisher=International Centre for Ethnic Studies |accessdate=25 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref> He was a member of the 2017-18 [[Provincial council (Sri Lanka)|provincial council]] [[delimitation]] committee.<ref name="ST040318">{{cite news |title=Provincial Councils’ Delimitation report in the House for debate |url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/180304/news/provincial-councils-delimitation-report-in-the-house-for-debate-284427.html |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=[[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)|The Sunday Times]] |date=4 March 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref><ref name="DN200218">{{cite news |title=Delimitation Report for PC elections handed over to Minister |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/02/20/political/143354/delimitation-report-pc-elections-handed-over-minister?page=18 |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=[[Daily News (Sri Lanka)]] |date=20 February 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref>
On 25 August 2018 Hasbullah suffered a [[heart attack]] during a meeting at the University of Jaffna and died after being admitted to [[Jaffna Teaching Hospital]].<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="Th250818"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Yuwaraj |first1=T. |title=பேராசிரியர் எஸ்.எச்.ஹஸ்புல்லாஹ் யாழ்ப்பாணம் பல்கலைக்கழக வளாகத்தில் காலமானார் |url=http://www.virakesari.lk/article/39124 |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=[[Virakesari]] |date=25 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka |language=Tamil}}</ref> His death came the day after the delimitation committee's report was rejected by [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|Parliament]] by 139 votes to nil.<ref name="EN250818">{{cite news |title=Co-author dies as Sri Lanka parliament shoots down report |url=https://economynext.com/Co_author_dies_as_Sri_Lanka_parliament_shoots_down_report-3-11658.html |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=Economy Next |date=25 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref> Hasbullah had submitted an alternate report opposing the delimitation committee's report which he believed had marginalised island-wide minority representation.<ref>{{cite news |title=சமூகத்திற்காக போராடி வென்ற பேராசிரியர் |url=http://vidivelli.lk/article/5792-%E0%AE%9A%E0%AE%AE%E0%AF%82%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%A4%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%A4%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%B1%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%95-%E0%AE%AA%E0%AF%8B%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%9F%E0%AE%BF-%E0%AE%B5%E0%AF%86%E0%AE%A9%E0%AF%8D%E0%AE%B1-%E0%AE%AA%E0%AF%87%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BE%E0%AE%9A%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%B0%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%AF%E0%AE%B0%E0%AF%8D.html |accessdate=4 September 2018 |work=Vidivelli News |date=30 August 2018 |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka}}</ref>
==Works== Hasbullah wrote several books and research papers including: * ''The Fertility Behaviour of Muslims of Sri Lanka'' (1984, [[University of British Columbia]])<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hasbullah |first1=S. H. |title=The Fertility Behaviour of Muslims of Sri Lanka |date=1984 |publisher=[[University of British Columbia]] |location=Vancouver, Canada |url=https://open.library.ubc.ca/media/download/pdf/831/1.0096353/1}}</ref> * ''The Growth and Variations of Rural Non-farm Activities in Sri Lanka Since Independence'' (1989, [[University of British Columbia]])<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hasbullah |first1=S. H. |title=The Growth and Variations of Rural Non-farm Activities in Sri Lanka Since Independence |date=1989 |publisher=[[University of British Columbia]] |location=Vancouver, Canada |url=https://open.library.ubc.ca/cIRcle/collections/ubctheses/831/items/1.0098761}}</ref> * ''Muslim Refugees, the Forgotten People in Sri Lanka's Ethnic Conflict'' (2001, Research and Action Forum for Social Development) * ''Peace Negotiations and Social Processes in Sri Lanka'' (2006, [[Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], co-author Øivind Fuglerud) * ''Sri Lankan Society in an Era of Globalization: Struggling to Create a New Social Order'' (2009, [[SAGE Publishing]], co-author Barrie M. Morrison)<ref name="Sage">{{cite web |title=S H Hasbullah |url=https://uk.sagepub.com/en-gb/eur/author/s-h-hasbullah |publisher=[[SAGE Publishing]] |accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref> * ''Checkpoint, Temple, Church and Mosque: A Collaborative Ethnography of War and Peace'' (2014, [[Pluto Press]], co-authors Jonathan Goodhand, Bart Klem, Benedikt Korf, Kalinga Tudor Silva and Jonathan Spencer)<ref name="CT250818"/><ref name="Pluto">{{cite web |title=Shahul Hasbullah |url=https://www.plutobooks.com/author/shahul-hasbullah/ |publisher=[[Pluto Press]] |accessdate=25 August 2018 |location=London, U.K.}}</ref> * ''Denying the Right to Return: Resettlement in Musali South and the Wilpattu Controversy'' (2015, Kandy Forum)<ref name="CT250818"/> * ''Social Mobilisation of Livelihood Concerns and Everyday Encounters with an Ambiguous State'' (ICES, co-author Urs Geiser)<ref name="CT250818"/>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hasbullah, S. H.}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Peradeniya]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Sri Lanka (Peradeniya)]] [[Category:Fulbright Scholars]] [[Category:People from Mannar District]] [[Category:Sri Lankan academics]] [[Category:Sri Lankan activists]] [[Category:Sri Lankan geographers]] [[Category:Sri Lankan writers]] [[Category:University of British Columbia alumni]]

revision.comment: /* Highest Resolution Global Release */ no need for (wrong) abbreviation of USGS; minor copy-edits elsewhere
revision.text:
[[File:Zagros Mountains, Iran, SRTM Shaded Relief Anaglyph.jpg|thumbnail|SRTM Shaded Relief Anaglyph of [[Zagros Mountains]].]] [[File:Srtm 1.jpg|thumb|250px|The SRTM was flown on an 11-day mission of the [[Space Shuttle Endeavour]] in February 2000.<ref name="NASA SRTM site">{{cite web|url=http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/srtm/|title=Shuttle Radar Topography Mission: Mission to Map the World|accessdate=2009-04-26|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20080823022748/http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/srtm/|archivedate=2008-08-23|df=}}</ref>]] [[File:Satellite image of Cape peninsula.jpg|thumb|right|250px|This NASA image used [[Landsat]] data to [[Texture mapping|texture-map]] the surface created using SRTM [[Elevation]] data. The [[Cape Peninsula]] and [[Cape of Good Hope]], [[South Africa]], are visible in the foreground.[http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA04961] ]] The '''Shuttle Radar Topography Mission''' ('''SRTM''') is an international research effort that obtained [[digital elevation model]]s on a near-global scale from [[56th parallel south|56°S]] to [[60th parallel north|60°N]],<ref name=NikP2>{{Harvnb|Nikolakopoulos|2006|p=2}}</ref> to generate the most complete high-resolution digital topographic database of Earth prior to the release of the [[ASTER GDEM]] in 2009. SRTM consisted of a specially modified [[radar]] system that flew on board the [[Space Shuttle]] [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Endeavour]] during the 11-day [[STS-99]] mission in February 2000, based on the older ''[[Spaceborne Imaging Radar|Spaceborne Imaging Radar-C/X-band Synthetic Aperture Radar]]'' (SIR-C/X-SAR), previously used on the Shuttle in 1994. To acquire [[Topography|topographic]] data, the SRTM payload was outfitted with two radar antennas.<ref name=NikP2/> One antenna was located in the Shuttle's payload bay, the other – a critical change from the SIR-C/X-SAR, allowing single-pass interferometry – on the end of a 60-meter (200-foot) mast that extended from the payload bay once the Shuttle was in space.<ref name=NikP2/> The technique employed is known as [[interferometric synthetic aperture radar]]. [[Intermap Technologies]] was the prime contractor for processing the [[interferometric synthetic aperture radar]] data.
The elevation models are arranged into tiles, each covering one [[degree (angle)|degree]] of latitude and one degree of longitude, named according to their south western corners. For example, "n45e006" stretches from [[45th parallel north|45°N]] [[6th meridian east|6°E]] to [[46th parallel north|46°N]] [[7th meridian east|7°E]] and "s45w006" from [[45th parallel south|45°S]] [[6th meridian west|6°W]] to [[44th parallel south|44°S]] [[5th meridian west|5°W]]. The resolution of the raw data is one [[arcsecond]] (30 m along the equator) and coverage includes Africa, Europe, North America, South America, Asia, and Australia.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASA Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) Version 3.0 Global 1 arc second Data Released over Asia and Australia Version 1.0|url=https://earthdata.nasa.gov/nasa-shuttle-radar-topography-mission-srtm-version-3-0-global-1-arc-second-data-released-over-asia-and-australia|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513032841/https://earthdata.nasa.gov/nasa-shuttle-radar-topography-mission-srtm-version-3-0-global-1-arc-second-data-released-over-asia-and-australia|archivedate=2017-05-13|df=}}</ref> A derived one arcsecond dataset with trees and other non-terrain features removed covering Australia was made available in November 2011; the raw data are restricted for government use.<ref>{{cite web|title=SRTM-derived 1 Second Digital Elevation Models Version 1.0|url=https://www.ga.gov.au/products/servlet/controller?event=GEOCAT_DETAILS&catno=72759|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228201506/https://www.ga.gov.au/products/servlet/controller?event=GEOCAT_DETAILS&catno=72759|archivedate=2012-02-28|df=}}</ref> For the rest of the world, only three arcsecond (90 m along the equator) data are available.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nikolakopoulos|2006|p=3}}</ref> Each one arcsecond tile has 3,601 rows, each consisting of 3,601 [[16 bit]] [[bigendian]] cells. The dimensions of the three arcsecond tiles are 1201 x 1201. The original SRTM elevations were calculated relative to the [[WGS84]] ellipsoid and then the [[EGM96]] geoid separation values were added to convert to heights relative to the geoid for all the released products.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hirt|first1=C.|last2=Filmer|first2=M.S. |last3=Featherstone|first3=W.E.|date=2010|title=Comparison and validation of recent freely-available ASTER-GDEM ver1, SRTM ver4.1 and GEODATA DEM-9S ver3 digital elevation models over Australia|journal=Australian Journal of Earth Sciences|volume=57|issue=3|pages=337–347|url=http://espace.library.curtin.edu.au:80/R?func=dbin-jump-full&local_base=gen01-era02&object_id=137777|accessdate=May 5, 2012|bibcode = 2010AuJES..57..337H |doi = 10.1080/08120091003677553 }}</ref>
The elevation models derived from the SRTM data are used in [[geographic information system]]s. They can be downloaded freely over the Internet, and their file format (.hgt) is widely supported.
The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission is an international project spearheaded by the U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency ([[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency|NGA]]) and the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration ([[NASA]]). NASA transferred the SRTM payload to the [[National Air and Space Museum|Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum]] in 2003; the canister, mast, and antenna are now on display at the [[Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center]] in [[Chantilly, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Cannister/Mast, Shuttle Radar Topography Mission Payload|url=http://airandspace.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?object=nasm_A20040261000|publisher=Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref>
== No-data areas == [[File:Srtm voidfilling grass gis.png|right|thumb|350px|SRTM void filling with spline interpolation in [[GRASS GIS]].]] The elevation datasets are affected by mountain and desert no-data areas. These amount to no more than 0.2% of the total area surveyed,<ref>Reuter H.I, A. Nelson, A. Jarvis, 2007, [http://www.cgiar-csi.org/images/stories/docs/Reuteretal2007.pdf An evaluation of void filling interpolation methods for SRTM data]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, International Journal of Geographic Information Science, 21:9, 983–1008 – 'the ‘finished’ grade version of the data (also referred to as Version 2) still contains data voids (some 836,000 km^2)'; 836,000 is 0.164% of the Earth's 5.1×10^8 km^2 surface</ref> but can be a problem in areas of very high relief. They affect all summits over 8,000 meters, most summits over 7,000 meters, many Alpine and similar summits and ridges, and many gorges and canyons. There are some SRTM data sources which have filled these data voids, but some of these have used only [[interpolation]] from surrounding data, and may therefore be very inaccurate. If the voids are large, or completely cover summit or ridge areas, no interpolation algorithms will give satisfactory results. Other developers, including [[NASA World Wind]] and [[Google Earth]], have improved their results by using 1-[[arc-second]] for the United States and 3-[[arc-second]] for the rest of the world, data in the interpolation process, but, due to the poor resolution of these data, and very poor quality of some of them, they have further improved their earth viewing services by adding data from other sources.
== Void-filled SRTM datasets == [[Image:Maps-for-free Sierra Nevada.png|thumb|250px|Relief map of [[Sierra Nevada (Spain)|Sierra Nevada, Spain]]]] [[File:SRTM1 Example Nevada.png|thumb|Example of relief map from SRTM1 (central Nevada)]]
Groups of scientists have worked on algorithms to fill the voids of the original SRTM data. Two datasets offer global coverage void-filled SRTM data at full resolution: the CGIAR-CSI versions<ref> {{cite web |url=http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org/ |publisher=[[Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research]] |accessdate=10 October 2014 |title=SRTM 90m Digital Elevation Data |date=19 August 2008 }}</ref> and the USGS HydroSHEDS dataset.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://hydrosheds.cr.usgs.gov/ |publisher = [[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate = 10 October 2014 |title = USGS HydroSHEDS |date = 6 September 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140928112952/http://hydrosheds.cr.usgs.gov/ |archivedate = 28 September 2014 |df = }}</ref>
The CGIAR-CSI version 4 provides the best global coverage full resolution SRTM dataset. The HydroSHEDS dataset was generated for hydrological applications and is suitable for consistent drainage and water flow information. References are provided<ref> {{cite web |url=http://hydrosheds.cr.usgs.gov/references.php |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate=10 October 2014 |title=USGS HydroSHEDS References |date=5 September 2010 }}</ref> on the algorithms used and quality assessment. The void-filled SRTM data from Viewfinder Panoramas<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.viewfinderpanoramas.org/dem3.html |publisher = Viewfinder Panoramas |accessdate = 10 October 2014 |title = DIGITAL ELEVATION DATA |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091210183954/http://www.viewfinderpanoramas.org/dem3.html |archivedate = 10 December 2009 |df = }}</ref> are high quality at full SRTM resolution. Since November 2012 there is free and global coverage at 3 arc seconds available.
In November 2013, LP DAAC released<ref> {{cite web |url = https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/about/news_archive/nasa_shuttle_radar_topography_mission_srtm_version_30_srtm_plus_product_release |publisher = [[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate = 10 October 2014 |title = NASA Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) Version 3.0 (SRTM Plus) Product Release |date = 14 April 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141017225451/https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/about/news_archive/nasa_shuttle_radar_topography_mission_srtm_version_30_srtm_plus_product_release |archivedate = 17 October 2014 |df = }}</ref> the NASA Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) Version 3.0 (SRTM Plus) Product collection with all voids eliminated. Voids were filled primarily from [[ASTER GDEM#ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model|ASTER GDEM2]], and secondarily from USGS GMTED2010 – or USGS National Elevation Dataset (NED) for the United States (except Alaska) and northernmost Mexico according to the announcement.
== Highest Resolution Global Release == 1-arc second global digital elevation model (30 meters) is available from the [[United States Geological Survey]] web site.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/|title=EarthExplorer|first=USGS - U.S. Geological|last=Survey|website=earthexplorer.usgs.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905062119/https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/|archivedate=2017-09-05|df=}}</ref> The United States Government announced on September 23, 2014 over a United Nations Climate Summit that the highest possible resolution of global topographic data derived from the SRTM mission will be released to public.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Releases Enhanced Shuttle Land Elevation Data|url=http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/srtm/|website=JPL-Shuttle Radar Topography Mission|accessdate=31 January 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20080823022748/http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/srtm/|archivedate=23 August 2008|df=}}</ref> Before the end of the same year, a 1-arc second global digital elevation model (30 meters) was released. Most parts of the world have been covered by this dataset ranging from 54°S to 60°N latitude except for the Middle East and North Africa area.<ref>{{cite web|title=USGS Earth Explorer|url=http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/|website=USGS-EarthExplorer|accessdate=31 January 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206111800/http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/|archivedate=6 February 2015|df=}}</ref> Missing coverage of the Middle East was completed in August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/nasa_shuttle_radar_topography_mission_srtm_global_1_arc_second_data_released_over_middle_east|title=NASA Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) Global 1 arc second Data Released Over the Middle East - LP DAAC :: NASA Land Data Products and Services|website=lpdaac.usgs.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913200035/https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/nasa_shuttle_radar_topography_mission_srtm_global_1_arc_second_data_released_over_middle_east|archivedate=2015-09-13|df=}}</ref>
==Users== In early June 2011, there were 750,000 confirmed users of SRTM topography dataset. Users in 221 countries have accessed the site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dapa.ciat.cgiar.org/dapas-srtm-topography-data-reaches-750000-users/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819172254/http://dapa.ciat.cgiar.org/dapas-srtm-topography-data-reaches-750000-users/ |archivedate=2011-08-19 |df= }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use British English|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox venue | name = O2 Guildhall Southampton | nickname = | image = Night exterior Southampton guildhall.jpg | image_caption = Exterior at night | image_size = 250 | pushpin_map = Southampton | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = O2 Guildhall in Southampton | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_relief = | address = W Marlands Rd
[[Southampton]] SO14 7LP
[[England]] | location = [[Civic Centre, Southampton|Civic Centre]] | coordinates = {{Coord|50.908154|-1.406003|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | type = | genre = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1937|02|13|df=yes}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Southampton City Council
(operated by [[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation UK]]) | construction_cost = | former_names = Southampton Guildhall (1937-2013) | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 1,749 | website = {{URL|http://www.o2guildhallsouthampton.co.uk/}} }} '''Southampton Guildhall''' (branded the '''O2 Guildhall Southampton''') is a multipurpose venue in the [[Civic Centre, Southampton|Civic Centre]] in [[Southampton]], England. The grade II* [[listed building]] was originally a [[Seat of local government|town hall]]. There are three venues in the Guildhall catering for various event formats: the Guildhall, the Solent Suite and a lecture theatre.[http://www.livenation.co.uk/southampton Southampton Guildhall Webpage] ==About== The Guildhall was designed to complement the rest of the Civic Suite and opened on 13 February 1937. It houses a large pipe organ which was built into it from new. The organ has two distinct consoles: a classical concert organ and a theatre organ. The consoles share the same body of approximately 4,000 pipes which are housed in chambers above the proscenium arch. It was the largest organ made by its builder, John Compton. On 7 October 2013, the venue was renamed to the O2 Guildhall Southampton, due to partnership between Live Nation UK and [[Telefónica Europe|O2 Telefónica]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-24427083 |title=Southampton Guildhall renaming 'cheapens' venue |author= |date=7 October 2013 |website=[[BBC News Online]] |publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=29 November 2013}} ==See also== * [[Guild]] * [[Guildhall Museum (disambiguation)|Guildhall Museum]] * [[Hanseatic League]] * [[Marketplace]] * [[Merchant]] * [[Retail]] ==References== Website with information about the venue's organ: [http://www.guildhall-compton.org.uk www.guildhall-compton.org.uk] {{reflist}} {{building-stub}} {{Live Nation}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Southampton]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Southampton]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox country telephone plan | country = Malta | country_link = Malta | continent = Europe | map_image = EU-Malta.svg | map_caption = {{map caption |location_color=dark green |region=Europe |region_color=dark grey |subregion=the [[European Union]] |subregion_color=green |legend=EU-Malta.svg}} | map_size = 200px | map_alt = | country_calling_code = +356 | international_prefix = 00 | trunk_prefix = | regulator = | plan_membership = | nsn_length = 8 | dial_plan_type = closed | number_format = | codes_list = }}
Malta adopted a new [[telephone numbering plan]] in 2001–2002, in which telephone numbers were expanded to eight digits for fixed line and mobile numbers. Previously, fixed line numbers were six digits, while mobile, mailbox and pager services were seven digits long.
==Geographic numbering== The prefix '''21''' was added to [[Maltacom]] fixed line numbers.
xx xxxx (before 2002, from within Malta) '''21'''xx xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 '''21'''xx xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta)
[[Melita (telecommunication company)|Melita]] fixed line numbers have the prefix '''27'''.<ref>[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20061124/local/hello-its-competition-time.34395#.UugjzNJFBkg Hello, it's competition time], ''[[Times of Malta]]'', 24 November 2006</ref>
Numbers were generally assigned according to locality: *22: [[Valletta]], [[Ħamrun]], [[Marsa, Malta|Marsa]] *23: [[Floriana]], [[Ħamrun]] *24: [[Pietà, Malta]] *25: [[Marsa, Malta|Marsa]] *32: [[Gżira]] *33: [[Tas-Sliema]], [[Msida]] *34: [[Gżira]], [[Msida]] *37: [[San Ġiljan]], [[Pembroke, Malta|Pembroke]], [[San Ġwann]] *38: ?? *41: [[Attard]], [[Għargħur]], [[Iklin]], [[Lija]], [[Mosta]], [[Naxxar]] *42: [[Lija]], [[Mosta]] *44: [[Qormi]], [[Balzan]], [[Birkirkara]] *45: [[Dingli]], [[Mdina]], [[Mtarfa]], [[Rabat, Malta]] *46: [[Żebbuġ, Malta]] *48: [[Qormi]], [[Birkirkara]] *49: [[Qormi]] *52: [[Mellieħa]], [[Mġarr]] *55: [[Gozo]] *56: [[Gozo]] *57: [[San Pawl il-Baħar]] *63: [[Marsaskala]] *64: [[Qrendi]], [[Safi, Malta|Safi]], [[Zurrieq]], [[Kirkop]] *65: [[Birżebbuġa]], [[Marsaxlokk]] *66: [[Żejtun]], [[Vittoriosa]], [[Bormla]], [[Fgura]], [[Għaxaq]], [[Senglea]], [[Kalkara]], [[Luqa]], [[Paola, Malta|Paola]] *67: [[Marsaxlokk]], [[Gudja]] *68: [[Kirkop]], [[Mqabba]], [[Qrendi]], [[Safi, Malta|Safi]] *69: [[Bormla]] *80: [[Żabbar]], [[Vittoriosa]], [[Fgura]]
==Non-geographic numbering==
The prefix '''9''' for seven-digit [[Vodafone Malta]] mobile phone numbers was changed to '''99'''.
9xx xxxx (before 2002, from within Malta) '''99'''xx xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 '''99'''xx xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta) The prefix '''09''' for Vodafone mobile phone numbers was changed to '''99'''.
Mobile phone numbers with the prefix '''09''', which were already eight digits, changed to '''99'''. The digit '''0''' was to be dialled from outside Malta as well as domestically.
09xx xxxx (before 2002, from within Malta) '''99'''xx xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 '''09'''xx xxxx (before 2002, outside Malta) +356 '''99'''xx xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta)
Other non-geographic number ranges also changed, with the prefix for seven-digit mailbox numbers changing from '''07''' to '''217'''.
07x xxxx (before 2002, from within Malta) '''217'''x xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 '''07'''x xxxx (before 2002, outside Malta) +356 '''217'''x xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta)
Similarly, the prefix for pager numbers changed from '''70''' and '''71''' to '''7117'''
70x xxxx (before 2002, from within Malta) '''7117''' xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 '''7117''' xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta) '''The prefix for Go Mobile is 79''' 79xx xxxx (after 2002, from within Malta) +356 79xx xxxx (after 2002, outside Malta)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Telephone numbers in Europe}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Chinese|order=st|title=''formally''
Township-level divisions|t=鄉級行政區|s=乡级行政区|p=Xiāng Jí Xíngzhèngqū|title2=Township (Xiang)|t2=鄉|s2=乡|p2=Xiāng|tib=ཤང་|zha=Yangh|mong={{MongolUnicode|ᠱᠢᠶᠠᠨ}}|monr=šiyan|uig=يېزىسى}} {{Administrative levels and divisions of China sidebar}} '''Townships''' ({{zh|s=乡|hp=Xiāng}}), formally '''township-level divisions''' ({{zh|s=乡级行政区|hp=Xiāng Jí Xíngzhèngqū|links=no}}), are the basic level (fourth-level administrative units) of [[Administrative divisions of the People's Republic of China#Township level|political divisions]] in [[China]]. They are similar to municipalities and communes in other countries and in turn may contain village committees and villages. In 1995 there were 29,502 townships and 17,532 towns (a total of 47,034 township-level divisions) in China.{{cite web |url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/apcity/unpan002813.pdf |title=China’s Township People's Congress Elections: An Introduction |last1=Yawei |first1=Liu|last2= |first2= |date= |website=un.org |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=2014-01-08}} Much like other levels of government in mainland China, the township's governance is divided between the Communist Party Township Secretary, and the "[[County magistrate (China)|county magistrate]]" ({{zh|s=乡长|hp=Xiāng zhǎng|links=no}}). The township party secretary, along with the township's party committee, determines policy. The magistrate is in charge of administering the daily affairs of government and executing policies as determined by the party committee. A township official is the lowest-level ranked official in the civil service hierarchy; in practice, however, the township party secretary and magistrate can amass high levels of personal power. A township government is formally responsible for local economic development, planning, maintenance of local roads, family planning (enforcing [[One-Child Policy]]), sanitation & health, sports, and "other responsibilities as determined by higher level governments".{{cite news|script-title=zh:乡政府职能和职责|url=http://wenku.baidu.com/view/b7a99b67783e0912a2162a86.html|publisher=''Baidu Wenku''}}{{better source|date=May 2018}} ==Types of townships== ===Urban=== *[[Subdistrict (China)|subdistricts]] ({{zh|c=街道|hp=jiēdào|links=no}}) *[[Town (China)|towns]] ({{zh|s=镇|hp=zhèn|links=no}}) ===Rural=== {{Main|Towns of China}} *[[Township (China)|townships]] ({{zh|s=乡|hp=xiang|links=no}}) ==List of township-level divisions== [[File:Townsips map guizhou.PNG|thumb|Township map of Guizhou]] [[File:Townsips map of Yunnan.PNG|thumb|Township map of Yunnan]] {| class="infobox" style="text-align: center; font-size: 0.9em; line-height: 1.3em;" |- ! style="background:#cbdcff; line-height: 1.2em; padding: 5px;"| {{nowrap|China Administrative divisions list}} |- | [[List of cities in the People's Republic of China|List of cities]]
(all types)
[[List of districts in the People's Republic of China|List of districts]] |- ! style="background: #e2ebff; padding: 4px;" | |- | [[List of prefectures in the People's Republic of China|List of prefectures]]
(all types) |- ! style="background: #e2ebff; padding: 4px;" | |- | [[List of counties in the People's Republic of China|List of counties]]
(all types) |- ! style="background: #e2ebff; padding: 4px;" | |- | '''List of township-level divisions''' |} ;Provinces *[[List of township-level divisions of Anhui]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Fujian]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Gansu]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Guangdong]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Guizhou]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Hainan]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Hebei]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Heilongjiang]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Henan]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Hubei]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Hunan]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Jiangsu]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Jiangxi]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Jilin]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Liaoning]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Qinghai]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Shaanxi]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Shandong]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Shanxi]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Sichuan]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Yunnan]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Zhejiang]] ; Autonomous areas *[[List of township-level divisions of Guangxi]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Inner Mongolia]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Ningxia]] *[[List of township-level divisions of the Tibet Autonomous Region]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Xinjiang]] ;Municipalities *[[List of township-level divisions of Beijing]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Chongqing]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Shanghai]] *[[List of township-level divisions of Tianjin]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.citypopulation.de/China-Townships.html Citypopulation.de: Population by township in China] {{Townships of China}} {{Articles on fourth-level administrative divisions of countries}} {{-}} [[Category:Township-level divisions of China| 01]] [[Category:Administrative divisions of China]] [[Category:Populated places in China]] [[Category:Townships|China]] [[Category:Fourth-level administrative country subdivisions|Townships, China]] {{China-stub}} {{Geo-term-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Tropical Green Building''' refers to a style of construction that focuses on energy reduction, reduced use of chemicals, and supporting local labor and community. This requires close cooperation of the design team, the architects, the engineers, and the client at all project stages, from site selection, scheme formation, material selection and procurement, to project implementation.<ref name="plainiotis">Ji Yan and Plainiotis Stellios (2006): Design for Sustainability. Beijing: China Architecture and Building Press. {{ISBN|7-112-08390-7}}</ref> Tropical [[Green building|Green Building]] has the same basis as green building in more [[temperate climate]]s, but the methods of construction are completely different. In the [[tropics]], the focus is on keeping cool, preventing insect infestations, and reduced mould, damp and maintenance in the home.
Generally, tropical green building also seeks to reduce [[power consumption]] through intelligent architecture, such as by allowing in lots of [[Sunlight|natural light]] so that [[electric light]]s aren't needed during the daytime, and at night, using white-painted roofs, ceilings and low-energy [[Incandescent light bulb|light bulbs]] such as [[Compact fluorescent lamp|compact fluorescent]]s or [[LED lamp]]s.
[[Solar power]], [[wind power]], and/or the use of [[micro hydro]] are often deployed, but not always the focus of tropical green building.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Tropical Green Building Network: Australia (TGBN) [http://www.greenbuild.com.au/ powered by GreenBuild.com.au] * 2013 Queensland Regional Architecture Conference: [https://web.archive.org/web/20130705215705/http://wp.architecture.com.au/spiritofplace/ Spirit of Place, Cairns 5 to 7 Sept 2013] * Singapore Green Building Council SB13 Conference: [http://www.sbsingapore.org/ SB13 Realising Sustainability in the Tropics 9 to 10 Sept 2013] * [http://www.drgbc.org/ Dominican Republic Green Building Council] (DRGBC)
[[Category:Low-energy building]] [[Category:Tropics]]

{{for|the bibliographic database about the geosciences|GeoRef}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2012}}
The '''World Geographic Reference System''' ('''GEOREF''') is a grid-based method of specifying locations on the surface of the [[Earth]]. GEOREF is essentially based on the geographic system of [[latitude]] and [[longitude]], but using a simpler and more flexible [[notation]]. GEOREF was used primarily for [[air navigation]],<ref>{{cite report |author=DMA |author-link=Defense Mapping Agency |date=20 September 1990 |title=Defense Mapping Agency Technical Manual |series=TM 8358.1 |chapter=Chapter 5: Geographic Coordinate References |chapter-url=http://earth-info.nga.mil/GandG/publications/tm8358.1/tr83581c.html#ZZ38 |access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref> particularly in military or inter-service applications, but it is rarely seen today. However, GEOREF can be used with any map or chart that has latitude and longitude printed on it.
== Operation ==
GEOREF is based on the standard system of [[latitude]] and [[longitude]], but uses a simpler and more concise notation. GEOREF divides the Earth's surface into successively smaller quadrangles, with a notation system used to identify each quadrangle within its parent. Unlike latitude/longitude, GEOREF runs in one direction horizontally, east from the 180° [[meridian (geography)|meridian]]; and one direction vertically, north from the [[South Pole]]. GEOREF can easily be adapted to give co-ordinates with varying degrees of precision, using a 2–12 character [[geocode]].
GEOREF co-ordinates are defined by successive divisions of the Earth's surface, as follows:
* The first level of GEOREF divides the world into quadrangles each measuring 15 degrees of longitude by 15 degrees of latitude; this results in 24 ''zones'' of longitude and 12 ''bands'' of latitude. A longitude zone is identified by a letter from A to Z (omitting I and O) starting at 180 degrees and progressing eastward through the full 360 degrees of longitude; a latitude band is identified by a letter from A through M (omitting I) northward from the south pole. Hence, any 15 degree quadrangle can be identified by two letters; the easting (longitude) is given first, followed by the northing (latitude). These two letters are the first two characters of a full GEOREF coordinate. * Each 15-degree quadrangle is further divided into smaller quadrangles, measuring 1 degree of longitude by 1 degree of latitude. These quadrangles are lettered A to Q (omitting I and O), running from west to east for longitude; and A to Q (omitting I and O), running south to north for latitude. These letters form the third and fourth characters of a full GEOREF coordinate. Four letters thus identify any 1-degree quadrangle in the world. * Each of the 1-degree quadrangles is further subdivided into 60 1-minute longitude zones, numbered 00 through 59 from west to east, and 60 1-minute latitude bands, numbered 00 to 59 from south to north. These numbers are always written as two digits, with a leading zero if necessary, and the easting is always followed by the northing. Thus, 4 letters and 4 digits give the position of any 1-minute quadrangle. * Each of the 1-minute quadrangles may be further divided into 10 or 100 smaller divisions both north–south and east–west, permitting the identification of 0.1-minute or 0.01-minute quadrangles. The GEOREF coordinate for any 0.1-minute quadrangle consists of four letters and six numbers; the GEOREF coordinate for any 0.01-minute quadrangle consists of four letters and eight numbers.
The initial two letters of a GEOREF reference, designating the 15 degree quadrangle, can be omitted, if it is clear which 15 degree quadrangle the reference applies to (e.g., when working within a restricted geographical area).
=== Example ===
[[Image:georef-local.jpg|thumb|256px|right|The GJ local grid]] For example, on a GEOREF chart, [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River]] (38°17′10″N 76°24′42″W) / (38.286108, -76.4291704) is located (to the nearest minute) at position GJPJ3716. <!-- Figure needed! In figure 12-10, the blacked-out square (PJ) within the enlarged 15° square (GJ) indicates the 1° area that contains Patuxent. -->
[[Image:Georef Example Patuxent.png|Breakdown of Georef co-ordinate GJPJ3716 into 15-degree quadrangle (GJ), 1-degree quadrangle (PJ), minutes east (37), and minutes north (16).]]
To locate the position from the coordinates, proceed as follows:
* Right from 180° longitude to longitude zone G * Up from the South Pole to latitude zone J * Right in zone GJ to the lettered 1° column P * Up in zone GJ to the lettered 1° row J * Right in the 1° horizontal zone to 37 minutes * Up in the 1° vertical zone to 16 minutes
The same co-ordinate shown in 6-digit (1/10 minute) format is GJPJ370160 and in 8-digit (1/100 minute) format is GJPJ37001600.
== Designation of area ==
Extensions to the above notation allow the GEOREF system to be used to designate an area around a reference point. This is achieved by adding an area designation to a base GEOREF co-ordinate. The area designation can be the letter S, to specify the sides of a rectangle (separated by the letter X); or the letter R, to specify the radius of a circle. In both cases the units are nautical miles. In addition, the letter H can be added, followed by an altitude in thousands of feet.
For example, the reference GJQJ0207S6X8 designates a rectangle centered on Deal Island (GJQJ0207), running {{convert|6|nmi|km|0}} east–west and {{convert|8|nmi|km|0}} north–south. Designation GJPJ4103R5 means a circle around Point Lookout (GJPJ4103) with a radius of {{convert|5|nmi|km|0}}. Designation GJPJ3716H17 means a height of 17,000 feet over GJPJ3716.
